QuoteText: Yes but asking your opponent for a definition usually reduces confusion. Even so, thanks I will attempt to use these in the event that databed accepts them. First let me categorize them. Young Earth creationism Humans Directly created by God. Plants/animals directly created by God. Macroevolution does not occur. Earth less than 10,000 years old. Reshaped by global flood. Universe Less than 10,000 years old. Belongs to the category 'God created life and this creation is it's explaination'. Gap creationism Humans Directly created by God. Plants/animals Directly created by God. Macroevolution does not occur. Earth scientifically accepted age. Reshaped by global flood. Universe scientifically accepted age. Belongs to the category 'God created life and this creation is it's explaination'. Progressive creationism Humans directly created by God (based on primate anatomy). Plans/animals direct creation + evolution. No single common ancestor. Earth scientifically accepted age. No global flood. Universe scientifically accepted age. Belongs to the category 'God created life and this creation is it's explaination'. Intelligent Design Proponents hold various beliefs. e.g. Behe accepts evolution from primates Divine intervention at some point in the past, as evidenced by what intelligent-design creationists call "irreducible complexity" Some adherents claim the existence of Earth is the result of divine intervention - Scientifically accepted age Belongs to the category 'God created life and this creation is it's explaination' albeit indirectly. Theistic evolution Humans evolved from primates. Evolution from single common ancestor. Earth scientifically accepted age. No global flood. Universe scientifically accepted age. Belongs to the category 'God created life and this creation is it's explaination' (the theistic part being that god designed the universe such that evolution of us had to happen). Given that every definition of creationism falls into that category I declare the key tenet of creationism is the belief that life is explained by God creating it. Since creationism can be said to be the belief that life is explained by god creating it, it as a whole falls under the category of 'explanations for life'. Since databed claims in this paragraph that 'Freedom has been very careful not to assert any explanation for life and its complexity', that universal must include the explaination of 'god created it'. Therefore this states at least "Freedom has been very careful not to assert that life is explained by God creating it". Since that belief is necessary and sufficient condition to be defined as a creationist the statement "Freedom has never asserted (supported in the sense of argument) creationism" can be deduced. The 'leap' from "Obviously Freedom is some form of a creationist, but he will not admit this." to "He is obviously a creationist" is one of simple rearranging.
ResponseText: In its broadest sense Creationist simply means believing that a deity created the universe. Within that there is obviously a range of beliefs. Theistic Evolution supporters have no conflict with scientific findings. Young Earthers reject science completely. Gap and Progressive Creationists find some sort of compromise position depending on their own emotions. IDers purposely set out to undermine scientific progress via legalistic means. They were defeated (or defeated themselves) and have fallen from their previously high profile, though some residual effects remain such as IC.
